      91                 :            : static constexpr int32_t MAX_PEER_TX_REQUEST_IN_FLIGHT = 100;
      92                 :            : /** Maximum number of transactions to consider for requesting, per peer. It provides a reasonable DoS limit to
      93                 :            :  *  per-peer memory usage spent on announcements, while covering peers continuously sending INVs at the maximum
      94                 :            :  *  rate (by our own policy, see INVENTORY_BROADCAST_PER_SECOND) for several minutes, while not receiving
      95                 :            :  *  the actual transaction (from any peer) in response to requests for them. */

     102                 :            : static constexpr auto OVERLOADED_PEER_TX_DELAY{2s};
     103                 :            : /** How long to wait before downloading a transaction from an additional peer */
     104                 :            : static constexpr auto GETDATA_TX_INTERVAL{60s};
     105                 :            : /** Limit to avoid sending big packets. Not used in processing incoming GETDATA for compatibility */
     106                 :            : static const unsigned int MAX_GETDATA_SZ = 1000;

     108                 :            : static const int MAX_BLOCKS_IN_TRANSIT_PER_PEER = 16;

     110                 :            : static constexpr auto BLOCK_STALLING_TIMEOUT{2s};
     111                 :            : /** Number of headers sent in one getheaders result. We rely on the assumption that if a peer sends
     112                 :            :  *  less than this number, we reached its tip. Changing this value is a protocol upgrade. */
     113                 :            : static const unsigned int MAX_HEADERS_RESULTS = 2000;
     114                 :            : /** Maximum depth of blocks we're willing to serve as compact blocks to peers
     115                 :            :  *  when requested. For older blocks, a regular BLOCK response will be sent. */
     116                 :            : static const int MAX_CMPCTBLOCK_DEPTH = 5;
     117                 :            : /** Maximum depth of blocks we're willing to respond to GETBLOCKTXN requests for. */
     118                 :            : static const int MAX_BLOCKTXN_DEPTH = 10;
     119                 :            : /** Size of the "block download window": how far ahead of our current height do we fetch?
     120                 :            :  *  Larger windows tolerate larger download speed differences between peer, but increase the potential
     121                 :            :  *  degree of disordering of blocks on disk (which make reindexing and pruning harder). We'll probably
     122                 :            :  *  want to make this a per-peer adaptive value at some point. */
     123                 :            : static const unsigned int BLOCK_DOWNLOAD_WINDOW = 1024;

     181                 :            : /** Blocks that are in flight, and that are in the queue to be downloaded. */

     188                 :            : 
     189                 :            : /**
     190                 :            :  * Data structure for an individual peer. This struct is not protected by

     192                 :            :  *
     193                 :            :  * Memory is owned by shared pointers and this object is destructed when
     194                 :            :  * the refcount drops to zero.
     195                 :            :  *
     196                 :            :  * Mutexes inside this struct must not be held when locking m_peer_mutex.

     198                 :            :  * TODO: move most members from CNodeState to this structure.

     241                 :            :     struct TxRelay {

     244                 :            :         // a) it allows us to not relay tx invs before receiving the peer's version message
     245                 :            :         // b) the peer may tell us in its version message that we should not relay tx invs
     246                 :            :         //    unless it loads a bloom filter.

     273                 :            :     /** Probabilistic filter to track recent addr messages relayed with this
     274                 :            :      *  peer. Used to avoid relaying redundant addresses to this peer.
     275                 :            :      *
     276                 :            :      *  We initialize this filter for outbound peers (other than
     277                 :            :      *  block-relay-only connections) or when an inbound peer sends us an
     278                 :            :      *  address related message (ADDR, ADDRV2, GETADDR).
     279                 :            :      *
     280                 :            :      *  Presence of this filter must correlate with m_addr_relay_enabled.
     281                 :            :      **/
     282                 :            :     std::unique_ptr<CRollingBloomFilter> m_addr_known;
     283                 :            :     /** Whether we are participating in address relay with this connection.
     284                 :            :      *
     285                 :            :      *  We set this bool to true for outbound peers (other than
     286                 :            :      *  block-relay-only connections), or when an inbound peer sends us an
     287                 :            :      *  address related message (ADDR, ADDRV2, GETADDR).
     288                 :            :      *
     289                 :            :      *  We use this bool to decide whether a peer is eligible for gossiping
     290                 :            :      *  addr messages. This avoids relaying to peers that are unlikely to
     291                 :            :      *  forward them, effectively blackholing self announcements. Reasons
     292                 :            :      *  peers might support addr relay on the link include that they connected
     293                 :            :      *  to us as a block-relay-only peer or they are a light client.
     294                 :            :      *
     295                 :            :      *  This field must correlate with whether m_addr_known has been
     296                 :            :      *  initialized.*/
     297                 :            :     std::atomic_bool m_addr_relay_enabled{false};
     298                 :            :     /** Whether a getaddr request to this peer is outstanding. */

     334                 :            : 
     335                 :            : using PeerRef = std::shared_ptr<Peer>;
     336                 :            : 
     337                 :            : /**
     338                 :            :  * Maintain validation-specific state about nodes, protected by cs_main, instead
     339                 :            :  * by CNode's own locks. This simplifies asynchronous operation, where
     340                 :            :  * processing of incoming data is done after the ProcessMessage call returns,
     341                 :            :  * and we're no longer holding the node's locks.
     342                 :            :  */
     343                 :            : struct CNodeState {
     344                 :            :     //! The best known block we know this peer has announced.
     345                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestKnownBlock{nullptr};
     346                 :            :     //! The hash of the last unknown block this peer has announced.
     347                 :            :     uint256 hashLastUnknownBlock{};
     348                 :            :     //! The last full block we both have.
     349                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexLastCommonBlock{nullptr};
     350                 :            :     //! The best header we have sent our peer.
     351                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestHeaderSent{nullptr};
     352                 :            :     //! Length of current-streak of unconnecting headers announcements
     353                 :            :     int nUnconnectingHeaders{0};
     354                 :            :     //! Whether we've started headers synchronization with this peer.
     355                 :            :     bool fSyncStarted{false};
     356                 :            :     //! When to potentially disconnect peer for stalling headers download
     357                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds m_headers_sync_timeout{0us};
     358                 :            :     //! Since when we're stalling block download progress (in microseconds), or 0.
     359                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds m_stalling_since{0us};
     360                 :            :     std::list<QueuedBlock> vBlocksInFlight;
     361                 :            :     //! When the first entry in vBlocksInFlight started downloading. Don't care when vBlocksInFlight is empty.
     362                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds m_downloading_since{0us};
     363                 :            :     int nBlocksInFlight{0};
     364                 :            :     //! Whether we consider this a preferred download peer.
     365                 :            :     bool fPreferredDownload{false};
     366                 :            :     //! Whether this peer wants invs or headers (when possible) for block announcements.
     367                 :            :     bool fPreferHeaders{false};
     368                 :            :     //! Whether this peer wants invs or cmpctblocks (when possible) for block announcements.
     369                 :            :     bool fPreferHeaderAndIDs{false};
     370                 :            :     /**
     371                 :            :       * Whether this peer will send us cmpctblocks if we request them.
     372                 :            :       * This is not used to gate request logic, as we really only care about fSupportsDesiredCmpctVersion,
     373                 :            :       * but is used as a flag to "lock in" the version of compact blocks (fWantsCmpctWitness) we send.
     374                 :            :       */
     375                 :            :     bool fProvidesHeaderAndIDs{false};
     376                 :            :     //! Whether this peer can give us witnesses
     377                 :            :     bool fHaveWitness{false};
     378                 :            :     //! Whether this peer wants witnesses in cmpctblocks/blocktxns
     379                 :            :     bool fWantsCmpctWitness{false};
     380                 :            :     /**
     381                 :            :      * If we've announced NODE_WITNESS to this peer: whether the peer sends witnesses in cmpctblocks/blocktxns,
     382                 :            :      * otherwise: whether this peer sends non-witnesses in cmpctblocks/blocktxns.
     383                 :            :      */
     384                 :            :     bool fSupportsDesiredCmpctVersion{false};
     385                 :            : 
     386                 :            :     /** State used to enforce CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT and EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL logic.
     387                 :            :       *
     388                 :            :       * Both are only in effect for outbound, non-manual, non-protected connections.
     389                 :            :       * Any peer protected (m_protect = true) is not chosen for eviction. A peer is
     390                 :            :       * marked as protected if all of these are true:
     391                 :            :       *   - its connection type is IsBlockOnlyConn() == false
     392                 :            :       *   - it gave us a valid connecting header
     393                 :            :       *   - we haven't reached MAX_OUTBOUND_PEERS_TO_PROTECT_FROM_DISCONNECT yet
     394                 :            :       *   - its chain tip has at least as much work as ours
     395                 :            :       *
     396                 :            :       * CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT: if a peer's best known block has less work than our tip,
     397                 :            :       * set a timeout CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT in the future:
     398                 :            :       *   - If at timeout their best known block now has more work than our tip
     399                 :            :       *     when the timeout was set, then either reset the timeout or clear it
     400                 :            :       *     (after comparing against our current tip's work)
     401                 :            :       *   - If at timeout their best known block still has less work than our
     402                 :            :       *     tip did when the timeout was set, then send a getheaders message,
     403                 :            :       *     and set a shorter timeout, HEADERS_RESPONSE_TIME seconds in future.
     404                 :            :       *     If their best known block is still behind when that new timeout is
     405                 :            :       *     reached, disconnect.
     406                 :            :       *
     407                 :            :       * EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL: after each interval, if we have too many outbound peers,
     408                 :            :       * drop the outbound one that least recently announced us a new block.
     409                 :            :       */
     410                 :            :     struct ChainSyncTimeoutState {
     411                 :            :         //! A timeout used for checking whether our peer has sufficiently synced
     412                 :            :         std::chrono::seconds m_timeout{0s};
     413                 :            :         //! A header with the work we require on our peer's chain
     414                 :            :         const CBlockIndex* m_work_header{nullptr};
     415                 :            :         //! After timeout is reached, set to true after sending getheaders
     416                 :            :         bool m_sent_getheaders{false};
     417                 :            :         //! Whether this peer is protected from disconnection due to a bad/slow chain
     418                 :            :         bool m_protect{false};
     419                 :            :     };
     420                 :            : 
     421                 :            :     ChainSyncTimeoutState m_chain_sync;
     422                 :            : 
     423                 :            :     //! Time of last new block announcement
     424                 :            :     int64_t m_last_block_announcement{0};
     425                 :            : 
     426                 :            :     //! Whether this peer is an inbound connection
     427                 :            :     const bool m_is_inbound;
     428                 :            : 
     429                 :            :     //! A rolling bloom filter of all announced tx CInvs to this peer.
     430                 :            :     CRollingBloomFilter m_recently_announced_invs = CRollingBloomFilter{INVENTORY_MAX_RECENT_RELAY, 0.000001};
     431                 :            : 
     432   [ +  -  +  -  :       1183 :     CNodeState(bool is_inbound) : m_is_inbound(is_inbound) {}
                   +  - ]
     433                 :            : };
     434                 :            : 
     435                 :            : class PeerManagerImpl final : public PeerManager
     436                 :            : {

     468                 :            : 
     469                 :            : private:
     470                 :            :     /** Consider evicting an outbound peer based on the amount of time they've been behind our tip */

     472                 :            : 
     473                 :            :     /** If we have extra outbound peers, try to disconnect the one with the oldest block announcement */

     475                 :            : 
     476                 :            :     /** Retrieve unbroadcast transactions from the mempool and reattempt sending to peers */

     478                 :            : 
     479                 :            :     /** Get a shared pointer to the Peer object.
     480                 :            :      *  May return an empty shared_ptr if the Peer object can't be found. */

     482                 :            :

     486                 :            : 
     487                 :            :     /**

     523                 :            :     /** Register with TxRequestTracker that an INV has been received from a
     524                 :            :      *  peer. The announcement parameters are decided in PeerManager and then

     526                 :            :     void AddTxAnnouncement(const CNode& node, const GenTxid& gtxid, std::chrono::microseconds current_time)

     534                 :            :      *  We use mockable time for ping timeouts, so setmocktime may cause pings

     536                 :            :     void MaybeSendPing(CNode& node_to, Peer& peer, std::chrono::microseconds now);

     540                 :            : 
     541                 :            :     /** Relay (gossip) an address to a few randomly chosen nodes.
     542                 :            :      *

     546                 :            :      *                         addresses less.
     547                 :            :      */
     548                 :            :     void RelayAddress(NodeId originator, const CAddress& addr, bool fReachable);
     549                 :            : 
     550                 :            :     /** Send `feefilter` message. */
     551                 :            :     void MaybeSendFeefilter(CNode& node, Peer& peer, std::chrono::microseconds current_time);
     552                 :            : 
     553                 :            :     const CChainParams& m_chainparams;
     554                 :            :     CConnman& m_connman;
     555                 :            :     AddrMan& m_addrman;
     556                 :            :     /** Pointer to this node's banman. May be nullptr - check existence before dereferencing. */
     557                 :            :     BanMan* const m_banman;
     558                 :            :     ChainstateManager& m_chainman;
     559                 :            :     CTxMemPool& m_mempool;
     560                 :            :     TxRequestTracker m_txrequest GUARDED_BY(::cs_main);
     561                 :            : 
     562                 :            :     /** The height of the best chain */
     563                 :            :     std::atomic<int> m_best_height{-1};
     564                 :            : 
     565                 :            :     /** Next time to check for stale tip */
     566                 :            :     std::chrono::seconds m_stale_tip_check_time{0s};
     567                 :            : 
     568                 :            :     /** Whether this node is running in blocks only mode */
     569                 :            :     const bool m_ignore_incoming_txs;
     570                 :            : 
     571                 :            :     /** Whether we've completed initial sync yet, for determining when to turn
     572                 :            :       * on extra block-relay-only peers. */
     573                 :            :     bool m_initial_sync_finished{false};
     574                 :            : 
     575                 :            :     /** Protects m_peer_map. This mutex must not be locked while holding a lock
     576                 :            :      *  on any of the mutexes inside a Peer object. */
     577                 :            :     mutable Mutex m_peer_mutex;
     578                 :            :     /**
     579                 :            :      * Map of all Peer objects, keyed by peer id. This map is protected
     580                 :            :      * by the m_peer_mutex. Once a shared pointer reference is
     581                 :            :      * taken, the lock may be released. Individual fields are protected by
     582                 :            :      * their own locks.
     583                 :            :      */
     584                 :            :     std::map<NodeId, PeerRef> m_peer_map GUARDED_BY(m_peer_mutex);
     585                 :            : 
     586                 :            :     /** Map maintaining per-node state. */
     587                 :            :     std::map<NodeId, CNodeState> m_node_states GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
     588                 :            : 
     589                 :            :     /** Get a pointer to a const CNodeState, used when not mutating the CNodeState object. */
     590                 :            :     const CNodeState* State(NodeId pnode) const EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     591                 :            :     /** Get a pointer to a mutable CNodeState. */
     592                 :            :     CNodeState* State(NodeId pnode) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     593                 :            : 
     594                 :            :     uint32_t GetFetchFlags(const CNode& pfrom) const EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     595                 :            : 
     596                 :            :     std::atomic<std::chrono::microseconds> m_next_inv_to_inbounds{0us};
     597                 :            : 
     598                 :            :     /** Number of nodes with fSyncStarted. */
     599                 :            :     int nSyncStarted GUARDED_BY(cs_main) = 0;
     600                 :            : 
     601                 :            :     /**
     602                 :            :      * Sources of received blocks, saved to be able punish them when processing
     603                 :            :      * happens afterwards.
     604                 :            :      * Set mapBlockSource[hash].second to false if the node should not be
     605                 :            :      * punished if the block is invalid.
     606                 :            :      */
     607                 :            :     std::map<uint256, std::pair<NodeId, bool>> mapBlockSource GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
     608                 :            : 
     609                 :            :     /** Number of peers with wtxid relay. */
     610                 :            :     std::atomic<int> m_wtxid_relay_peers{0};
     611                 :            : 
     612                 :            :     /** Number of outbound peers with m_chain_sync.m_protect. */
     613                 :            :     int m_outbound_peers_with_protect_from_disconnect GUARDED_BY(cs_main) = 0;
     614                 :            : 
     615                 :            :     /** Number of preferable block download peers. */
     616                 :            :     int m_num_preferred_download_peers GUARDED_BY(cs_main){0};
     617                 :            : 
     618                 :            :     bool AlreadyHaveTx(const GenTxid& gtxid) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     619                 :            : 
     620                 :            :     /**
     621                 :            :      * Filter for transactions that were recently rejected by the mempool.
     622                 :            :      * These are not rerequested until the chain tip changes, at which point
     623                 :            :      * the entire filter is reset.
     624                 :            :      *
     625                 :            :      * Without this filter we'd be re-requesting txs from each of our peers,
     626                 :            :      * increasing bandwidth consumption considerably. For instance, with 100
     627                 :            :      * peers, half of which relay a tx we don't accept, that might be a 50x
     628                 :            :      * bandwidth increase. A flooding attacker attempting to roll-over the
     629                 :            :      * filter using minimum-sized, 60byte, transactions might manage to send
     630                 :            :      * 1000/sec if we have fast peers, so we pick 120,000 to give our peers a
     631                 :            :      * two minute window to send invs to us.
     632                 :            :      *
     633                 :            :      * Decreasing the false positive rate is fairly cheap, so we pick one in a
     634                 :            :      * million to make it highly unlikely for users to have issues with this
     635                 :            :      * filter.
     636                 :            :      *
     637                 :            :      * We typically only add wtxids to this filter. For non-segwit
     638                 :            :      * transactions, the txid == wtxid, so this only prevents us from
     639                 :            :      * re-downloading non-segwit transactions when communicating with
     640                 :            :      * non-wtxidrelay peers -- which is important for avoiding malleation
     641                 :            :      * attacks that could otherwise interfere with transaction relay from
     642                 :            :      * non-wtxidrelay peers. For communicating with wtxidrelay peers, having
     643                 :            :      * the reject filter store wtxids is exactly what we want to avoid
     644                 :            :      * redownload of a rejected transaction.
     645                 :            :      *
     646                 :            :      * In cases where we can tell that a segwit transaction will fail
     647                 :            :      * validation no matter the witness, we may add the txid of such
     648                 :            :      * transaction to the filter as well. This can be helpful when
     649                 :            :      * communicating with txid-relay peers or if we were to otherwise fetch a
     650                 :            :      * transaction via txid (eg in our orphan handling).
     651                 :            :      *
     652                 :            :      * Memory used: 1.3 MB
     653                 :            :      */
     654                 :            :     CRollingBloomFilter m_recent_rejects GUARDED_BY(::cs_main){120'000, 0.000'001};
     655                 :            :     uint256 hashRecentRejectsChainTip GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
     656                 :            : 
     657                 :            :     /*
     658                 :            :      * Filter for transactions that have been recently confirmed.
     659                 :            :      * We use this to avoid requesting transactions that have already been
     660                 :            :      * confirnmed.
     661                 :            :      *
     662                 :            :      * Blocks don't typically have more than 4000 transactions, so this should
     663                 :            :      * be at least six blocks (~1 hr) worth of transactions that we can store,
     664                 :            :      * inserting both a txid and wtxid for every observed transaction.
     665                 :            :      * If the number of transactions appearing in a block goes up, or if we are
     666                 :            :      * seeing getdata requests more than an hour after initial announcement, we
     667                 :            :      * can increase this number.
     668                 :            :      * The false positive rate of 1/1M should come out to less than 1
     669                 :            :      * transaction per day that would be inadvertently ignored (which is the
     670                 :            :      * same probability that we have in the reject filter).
     671                 :            :      */
     672                 :            :     Mutex m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex;
     673                 :            :     CRollingBloomFilter m_recent_confirmed_transactions GUARDED_BY(m_recent_confirmed_transactions_mutex){48'000, 0.000'001};
     674                 :            : 
     675                 :            :     /**
     676                 :            :      * For sending `inv`s to inbound peers, we use a single (exponentially
     677                 :            :      * distributed) timer for all peers. If we used a separate timer for each
     678                 :            :      * peer, a spy node could make multiple inbound connections to us to
     679                 :            :      * accurately determine when we received the transaction (and potentially
     680                 :            :      * determine the transaction's origin). */
     681                 :            :     std::chrono::microseconds NextInvToInbounds(std::chrono::microseconds now,
     682                 :            :                                                 std::chrono::seconds average_interval);
     683                 :            : 
     684                 :            : 
     685                 :            :     // All of the following cache a recent block, and are protected by m_most_recent_block_mutex
     686                 :            :     RecursiveMutex m_most_recent_block_mutex;
     687                 :            :     std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> m_most_recent_block GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     688                 :            :     std::shared_ptr<const CBlockHeaderAndShortTxIDs> m_most_recent_compact_block GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     689                 :            :     uint256 m_most_recent_block_hash GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     690                 :            :     bool m_most_recent_compact_block_has_witnesses GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex){false};
     691                 :            : 
     692                 :            :     /** Height of the highest block announced using BIP 152 high-bandwidth mode. */
     693                 :            :     int m_highest_fast_announce{0};
     694                 :            : 
     695                 :            :     /** Have we requested this block from a peer */
     696                 :            :     bool IsBlockRequested(const uint256& hash) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     697                 :            : 
     698                 :            :     /** Remove this block from our tracked requested blocks. Called if:
     699                 :            :      *  - the block has been received from a peer
     700                 :            :      *  - the request for the block has timed out
     701                 :            :      */
     702                 :            :     void RemoveBlockRequest(const uint256& hash) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     703                 :            : 
     704                 :            :     /* Mark a block as in flight
     705                 :            :      * Returns false, still setting pit, if the block was already in flight from the same peer
     706                 :            :      * pit will only be valid as long as the same cs_main lock is being held
     707                 :            :      */
     708                 :            :     bool BlockRequested(NodeId nodeid, const CBlockIndex& block, std::list<QueuedBlock>::iterator** pit = nullptr) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     709                 :            : 
     710                 :            :     bool TipMayBeStale() EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     711                 :            : 
     712                 :            :     /** Update pindexLastCommonBlock and add not-in-flight missing successors to vBlocks, until it has
     713                 :            :      *  at most count entries.
     714                 :            :      */
     715                 :            :     void FindNextBlocksToDownload(NodeId nodeid, unsigned int count, std::vector<const CBlockIndex*>& vBlocks, NodeId& nodeStaller) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     716                 :            : 
     717                 :            :     std::map<uint256, std::pair<NodeId, std::list<QueuedBlock>::iterator> > mapBlocksInFlight GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
     718                 :            : 
     719                 :            :     /** When our tip was last updated. */
     720                 :            :     std::atomic<std::chrono::seconds> m_last_tip_update{0s};
     721                 :            : 
     722                 :            :     /** Determine whether or not a peer can request a transaction, and return it (or nullptr if not found or not allowed). */
     723                 :            :     CTransactionRef FindTxForGetData(const CNode& peer, const GenTxid& gtxid, const std::chrono::seconds mempool_req, const std::chrono::seconds now) LOCKS_EXCLUDED(cs_main);
     724                 :            : 
     725                 :            :     void ProcessGetData(CNode& pfrom, Peer& peer, const std::atomic<bool>& interruptMsgProc) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(peer.m_getdata_requests_mutex) LOCKS_EXCLUDED(::cs_main);
     726                 :            : 
     727                 :            :     /** Process a new block. Perform any post-processing housekeeping */
     728                 :            :     void ProcessBlock(CNode& node, const std::shared_ptr<const CBlock>& block, bool force_processing);
     729                 :            : 
     730                 :            :     /** Relay map (txid or wtxid -> CTransactionRef) */
     731                 :            :     typedef std::map<uint256, CTransactionRef> MapRelay;
     732                 :            :     MapRelay mapRelay GUARDED_BY(cs_main);

    1117                 :            :     // linked block we have in common with this peer. The +1 is so we can detect stalling, namely if we would be able to
    1118                 :            :     // download that next block if the window were 1 larger.

    1369                 :            :     // It is common for nodes with good ping times to suddenly become lagged,
    1370                 :            :     // due to a new block arriving or other large transfer.
    1371                 :            :     // Merely reporting pingtime might fool the caller into thinking the node was still responsive,
    1372                 :            :     // since pingtime does not update until the ping is complete, which might take a while.
    1373                 :            :     // So, if a ping is taking an unusually long time in flight,
    1374                 :            :     // the caller can immediately detect that this is happening.

    1573                 :        740 : void PeerManagerImpl::StartScheduledTasks(CScheduler& scheduler)
    1574                 :            : {
    1575                 :            :     // Stale tip checking and peer eviction are on two different timers, but we
    1576                 :            :     // don't want them to get out of sync due to drift in the scheduler, so we

    1578                 :            :     // timer.

    1615                 :       3465 : void PeerManagerImpl::BlockDisconnected(const std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> &block, const CBlockIndex* pindex)
    1616                 :            : {
    1617                 :            :     // To avoid relay problems with transactions that were previously
    1618                 :            :     // confirmed, clear our filter of recently confirmed transactions whenever
    1619                 :            :     // there's a reorg.
    1620                 :            :     // This means that in a 1-block reorg (where 1 block is disconnected and
    1621                 :            :     // then another block reconnected), our filter will drop to having only one
    1622                 :            :     // block's worth of transactions in it, but that should be fine, since
    1623                 :            :     // presumably the most common case of relaying a confirmed transaction

    1759                 :      56702 : bool PeerManagerImpl::AlreadyHaveTx(const GenTxid& gtxid)

    1763                 :            :         // might be now valid, e.g. due to a nLockTime'd tx becoming valid,

    1808                 :         53 : void PeerManagerImpl::RelayAddress(NodeId originator,
    1809                 :            :                                    const CAddress& addr,
    1810                 :            :                                    bool fReachable)
    1811                 :            : {
    1812                 :            :     // We choose the same nodes within a given 24h window (if the list of connected
    1813                 :            :     // nodes does not change) and we don't relay to nodes that already know an
    1814                 :            :     // address. So within 24h we will likely relay a given address once. This is to
    1815                 :            :     // prevent a peer from unjustly giving their address better propagation by sending
    1816                 :            :     // it to us repeatedly.
    1817                 :            : 
    1818   [ +  +  -  +  :         53 :     if (!fReachable && !addr.IsRelayable()) return;
                   -  + ]
    1819                 :            : 
    1820                 :            :     // Relay to a limited number of other nodes
    1821                 :            :     // Use deterministic randomness to send to the same nodes for 24 hours
    1822                 :            :     // at a time so the m_addr_knowns of the chosen nodes prevent repeats
    1823                 :         53 :     const uint64_t hash_addr{CServiceHash(0, 0)(addr)};
    1824                 :         53 :     const auto current_time{GetTime<std::chrono::seconds>()};
    1825                 :            :     // Adding address hash makes exact rotation time different per address, while preserving periodicity.
    1826                 :         53 :     const uint64_t time_addr{(static_cast<uint64_t>(count_seconds(current_time)) + hash_addr) / count_seconds(ROTATE_ADDR_RELAY_DEST_INTERVAL)};
    1827                 :         53 :     const CSipHasher hasher{m_connman.GetDeterministicRandomizer(RANDOMIZER_ID_ADDRESS_RELAY)
    1828                 :         53 :                                 .Write(hash_addr)
    1829                 :         53 :                                 .Write(time_addr)};
    1830                 :         53 :     FastRandomContext insecure_rand;
    1831                 :            : 
    1832                 :            :     // Relay reachable addresses to 2 peers. Unreachable addresses are relayed randomly to 1 or 2 peers.
    1833   [ +  +  +  - ]:         53 :     unsigned int nRelayNodes = (fReachable || (hasher.Finalize() & 1)) ? 2 : 1;
    1834                 :            : 
    1835                 :         53 :     std::array<std::pair<uint64_t, Peer*>, 2> best{{{0, nullptr}, {0, nullptr}}};
    1836         [ -  + ]:         53 :     assert(nRelayNodes <= best.size());
    1837                 :            : 
    1838                 :        106 :     LOCK(m_peer_mutex);
    1839                 :            : 
    1840         [ +  + ]:        622 :     for (auto& [id, peer] : m_peer_map) {
    1841   [ +  +  +  +  :        569 :         if (peer->m_addr_relay_enabled && id != originator && IsAddrCompatible(*peer, addr)) {
          +  -  +  -  +  
                      + ]
    1842   [ +  -  +  - ]:        512 :             uint64_t hashKey = CSipHasher(hasher).Write(id).Finalize();
    1843         [ +  + ]:       1225 :             for (unsigned int i = 0; i < nRelayNodes; i++) {
    1844         [ +  + ]:        904 :                  if (hashKey > best[i].first) {
    1845         [ +  - ]:        191 :                      std::copy(best.begin() + i, best.begin() + nRelayNodes - 1, best.begin() + i + 1);

    2113                 :            :         // have to wait around forever.
    2114                 :            :         // SPV clients care about this message: it's needed when they are
    2115                 :            :         // recursively walking the dependencies of relevant unconfirmed
    2116                 :            :         // transactions. SPV clients want to do that because they want to know
    2117                 :            :         // about (and store and rebroadcast and risk analyze) the dependencies
    2118                 :            :         // of transactions relevant to them, without having to download the
    2119                 :            :         // entire memory pool.
    2120                 :            :         // Also, other nodes can use these messages to automatically request a
    2121                 :            :         // transaction from some other peer that annnounced it, and stop
    2122                 :            :         // waiting for us to respond.
    2123                 :            :         // In normal operation, we often send NOTFOUND messages for parents of
    2124                 :            :         // transactions that we relay; if a peer is missing a parent, they may

    2344                 :            : /**
    2345                 :            :  * Reconsider orphan transactions after a parent has been accepted to the mempool.
    2346                 :            :  *
    2347                 :            :  * @param[in,out]  orphan_work_set  The set of orphan transactions to reconsider. Generally only one
    2348                 :            :  *                                  orphan will be reconsidered on each call of this function. This set

    2351                 :            :  */

    2384                 :            :             }

    2386                 :            :             // Probably non-standard or insufficient fee

          +  -  +  -  +  
                -  +  - ]
    2388         [ +  - ]:          2 :             if (state.GetResult() != TxValidationResult::TX_WITNESS_STRIPPED) {
    2389                 :            :                 // We can add the wtxid of this transaction to our reject filter.
    2390                 :            :                 // Do not add txids of witness transactions or witness-stripped
    2391                 :            :                 // transactions to the filter, as they can have been malleated;
    2392                 :            :                 // adding such txids to the reject filter would potentially
    2393                 :            :                 // interfere with relay of valid transactions from peers that
    2394                 :            :                 // do not support wtxid-based relay. See
    2395                 :            :                 // https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8279 for details.
    2396                 :            :                 // We can remove this restriction (and always add wtxids to
    2397                 :            :                 // the filter even for witness stripped transactions) once
    2398                 :            :                 // wtxid-based relay is broadly deployed.
    2399                 :            :                 // See also comments in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18044#discussion_r443419034
    2400                 :            :                 // for concerns around weakening security of unupgraded nodes
    2401                 :            :                 // if we start doing this too early.
    2402   [ +  -  +  - ]:          2 :                 m_recent_rejects.insert(porphanTx->GetWitnessHash());
    2403                 :            :                 // If the transaction failed for TX_INPUTS_NOT_STANDARD,
    2404                 :            :                 // then we know that the witness was irrelevant to the policy
    2405                 :            :                 // failure, since this check depends only on the txid
    2406                 :            :                 // (the scriptPubKey being spent is covered by the txid).
    2407                 :            :                 // Add the txid to the reject filter to prevent repeated
    2408                 :            :                 // processing of this transaction in the event that child
    2409                 :            :                 // transactions are later received (resulting in
    2410                 :            :                 // parent-fetching by txid via the orphan-handling logic).

    2413                 :            :                     // avoid wasting entries in the rolling bloom filter.

    3313                 :            :         // pindex can be nullptr either if we sent m_chainman.ActiveChain().Tip() OR
    3314                 :            :         // if our peer has m_chainman.ActiveChain().Tip() (and thus we are sending an empty
    3315                 :            :         // headers message). In both cases it's safe to update
    3316                 :            :         // pindexBestHeaderSent to be our tip.
    3317                 :            :         //
    3318                 :            :         // It is important that we simply reset the BestHeaderSent value here,
    3319                 :            :         // and not max(BestHeaderSent, newHeaderSent). We might have announced
    3320                 :            :         // the currently-being-connected tip using a compact block, which
    3321                 :            :         // resulted in the peer sending a headers request, which we respond to
    3322                 :            :         // without the new block. By resetting the BestHeaderSent, we ensure we
    3323                 :            :         // will re-announce the new block via headers (or compact blocks again)
    3324                 :            :         // in the SendMessages logic.

    3340                 :            :         // Stop processing the transaction early if we are still in IBD since we don't
    3341                 :            :         // have enough information to validate it yet. Sending unsolicited transactions
    3342                 :            :         // is not considered a protocol violation, so don't punish the peer.
    3343   [ +  -  +  -  :      10741 :         if (m_chainman.ActiveChainstate().IsInitialBlockDownload()) return;

    3367                 :            : 
    3368                 :            :         // We do the AlreadyHaveTx() check using wtxid, rather than txid - in the
    3369                 :            :         // absence of witness malleation, this is strictly better, because the
    3370                 :            :         // recent rejects filter may contain the wtxid but rarely contains
    3371                 :            :         // the txid of a segwit transaction that has been rejected.
    3372                 :            :         // In the presence of witness malleation, it's possible that by only
    3373                 :            :         // doing the check with wtxid, we could overlook a transaction which
    3374                 :            :         // was confirmed with a different witness, or exists in our mempool
    3375                 :            :         // with a different witness, but this has limited downside:
    3376                 :            :         // mempool validation does its own lookup of whether we have the txid
    3377                 :            :         // already; and an adversary can already relay us old transactions
    3378                 :            :         // (older than our recency filter) if trying to DoS us, without any need

    3486                 :            :                 // adding such txids to the reject filter would potentially
    3487                 :            :                 // interfere with relay of valid transactions from peers that

    3491                 :            :                 // the filter even for witness stripped transactions) once

    3953         [ +  + ]:       6151 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::PING) {
    3954         [ +  - ]:       3163 :         if (pfrom.GetCommonVersion() > BIP0031_VERSION) {
    3955                 :       3163 :             uint64_t nonce = 0;
    3956         [ +  - ]:       3163 :             vRecv >> nonce;
    3957                 :            :             // Echo the message back with the nonce. This allows for two useful features:
    3958                 :            :             //
    3959                 :            :             // 1) A remote node can quickly check if the connection is operational
    3960                 :            :             // 2) Remote nodes can measure the latency of the network thread. If this node
    3961                 :            :             //    is overloaded it won't respond to pings quickly and the remote node can
    3962                 :            :             //    avoid sending us more work, like chain download requests.
    3963                 :            :             //
    3964                 :            :             // The nonce stops the remote getting confused between different pings: without
    3965                 :            :             // it, if the remote node sends a ping once per second and this node takes 5
    3966                 :            :             // seconds to respond to each, the 5th ping the remote sends would appear to
    3967                 :            :             // return very quickly.
    3968   [ +  -  +  -  :       3163 :             m_connman.PushMessage(&pfrom, msgMaker.Make(NetMsgType::PONG, nonce));
                   +  - ]
    3969                 :            :         }
    3970                 :       3163 :         return;
    3971                 :            :     }
    3972                 :            : 
    3973         [ +  + ]:       2988 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::PONG) {
    3974                 :       2016 :         const auto ping_end = time_received;
    3975                 :       2016 :         uint64_t nonce = 0;
    3976                 :       2016 :         size_t nAvail = vRecv.in_avail();
    3977                 :       2016 :         bool bPingFinished = false;
    3978                 :       2016 :         std::string sProblem;
    3979                 :            : 
    3980         [ +  + ]:       2016 :         if (nAvail >= sizeof(nonce)) {
    3981         [ +  - ]:       2015 :             vRecv >> nonce;
    3982                 :            : 
    3983                 :            :             // Only process pong message if there is an outstanding ping (old ping without nonce should never pong)

    3985         [ +  + ]:       2014 :                 if (nonce == peer->m_ping_nonce_sent) {
    3986                 :            :                     // Matching pong received, this ping is no longer outstanding
    3987                 :       2012 :                     bPingFinished = true;
    3988                 :       2012 :                     const auto ping_time = ping_end - peer->m_ping_start.load();
    3989         [ +  - ]:       2012 :                     if (ping_time.count() >= 0) {
    3990                 :            :                         // Let connman know about this successful ping-pong
    3991         [ +  - ]:       2012 :                         pfrom.PongReceived(ping_time);
    3992                 :            :                     } else {
    3993                 :            :                         // This should never happen

    4325                 :        215 : void PeerManagerImpl::EvictExtraOutboundPeers(std::chrono::seconds now)
    4326                 :            : {
    4327                 :            :     // If we have any extra block-relay-only peers, disconnect the youngest unless
    4328                 :            :     // it's given us a block -- in which case, compare with the second-youngest, and
    4329                 :            :     // out of those two, disconnect the peer who least recently gave us a block.
    4330                 :            :     // The youngest block-relay-only peer would be the extra peer we connected
    4331                 :            :     // to temporarily in order to sync our tip; see net.cpp.
    4332                 :            :     // Note that we use higher nodeid as a measure for most recent connection.
    4333         [ +  + ]:        215 :     if (m_connman.GetExtraBlockRelayCount() > 0) {

    5005                 :            :             // Stalling only triggers when the block download window cannot move. During normal steady state,
    5006                 :            :             // the download window should be much larger than the to-be-downloaded set of blocks, so disconnection
    5007                 :            :             // should only happen during initial block download.

    5009                 :          0 :             pto->fDisconnect = true;
    5010                 :          0 :             return true;
    5011                 :            :         }
    5012                 :            :         // In case there is a block that has been in flight from this peer for block_interval * (1 + 0.5 * N)
    5013                 :            :         // (with N the number of peers from which we're downloading validated blocks), disconnect due to timeout.
    5014                 :            :         // We compensate for other peers to prevent killing off peers due to our own downstream link
    5015                 :            :         // being saturated. We only count validated in-flight blocks so peers can't advertise non-existing block hashes
    5016                 :            :         // to unreasonably increase our timeout.
